description: South Korea charges Korean Air and three sister companies in Hanjin Group evaded $370 million in taxes in biggest tax evasion scheme in nation's history; charges carrier siphoned $442 million in foreign currency out nation; holds group founder, Cho Joong-hoon, and his two sons, Cho Yang-ho and Cho Su-ho, were directly involved in scheme (S)
title: WORLD BUSINESS BRIEFING: ASIA; TAX EVASION CHARGED
title_page: WORLD BUSINESS BRIEFING: ASIA; TAX EVASION CHARGED - The New York Times
maintext: The South Korean Government accused Korean Air and three sister companies of evading $370 million in taxes and said the country's flag carrier had siphoned $442 million in foreign currency out of the country. Officials characterized the findings as the biggest tax evasion scheme in South Korea's history. The findings will be reported to state prosecutors. Korean Air and the sister companies are part of the Hanjin group. Cho Joong-hoon, founder of the Hanjin group, and his two sons -- Cho Yang-ho and Cho Su-ho -- were accused of direct involvement in the scheme.
